content.text: We often need to draw conclusions about a whole **population** based on a **sample**. Polls, scientific studies, and quality control all rely on sampling. But samples can mislead if not done properly.

content.definition: An argument that reasons from a sample to a conclusion about the whole population. From 'X% of the sample has property P', we conclude 'approximately X% of the population has P'.

content.title: Inductive Generalization
content.conclusion: Therefore, approximately 62% of all voters support the policy.
content.note: The conclusion is probable, not certain. The actual population percentage might differ.

symbols.name: Each Has Equal Chance
symbols.meaning: Every member equally likely to be selected

content.definition: A systematic error that occurs when the sample is not randomly selected, making it unrepresentative of the population.

content.title: Selection Bias
premises: A magazine surveys its readers about a policy.
content.conclusion: We CANNOT conclude 75% of the general public opposes it.
content.note: Magazine readers are self-selected and may not represent the general population.

content.question: A website poll shows 80% support for a candidate. Why might this be unreliable?
options: 80% is too high to be accurate
Website visitors are self-selected and may not represent all voters
The sample size is too small
content.explanation: Website visitors choose to visit (self-selection) and may share characteristics that differ from the general population. They might skew younger, more tech-savvy, or have particular interests. This creates selection bias that can make the sample unrepresentative.
